reviewText:
Yotsuba aka Clover-TAC is the man behind doujin danmaku darling Crimzon Clover. This game is not just the result of five years of hard work. Yotsuba is phenomenal at shmups, has world records in Cave's ESP RA.DE, and worked as a tester on Arika's Playstation 2 port of Dodonpachi Daioujou. In short, he knows his stuff.

So, aspiring shmup developers, is all this really necessary? Do you have to be a 2D shooter God in order to make a good game in the genre? Not everyone has that level of dedication, I understand that. But if Artnumeris put forth even 1% the effort Yotsuba did, maybe C-RUSH wouldn't have turned out to be such a horrible pile of bull-♥♥♥♥. I've read a number of reviews for this game. Most of them say they couldn't even get the game to run. I guess they lucked out. Playing C-RUSH will ruin a perfectly good day.

The first thing that set off my uhoh this game is booty" alarm is the way the ship moves. When moving forward
date: the ship looks like its v-sync is screwed up and it glitches out as a result. This doesn't affect the game
recommended: but it looks really poor. What does affect the game is the hitches and pauses. The first achievement you'll get is for attaining an 8x multiplier. When I got the achievement the screen juddered for a half-second. I brushed it aside at first
hoursPlayed: because sometimes achievements can cause ever-so-slight hang-ups during the game. As it turns out
voteText:
this happens everytime I hit that multiplier. Stuttering is a constant in this game.

BUT THAT'S NOT ALL!
The weapon-system makes no sense. The player-ship has two fire modes
helpfulPercent: single-fire or twin-cannons. All players are going to choose the mode that offers more fire-power. This game tries to force the single-fire on you
votesHelpful: by lining certain enemies up in a particular way
votesTotal: or making exceptionally tight corridors. This really doesn't work. You know what also doesn't work? Giving the weapons some weird ammo system. You have to touch this strange gas to recharge your weapons
votesFunny:
or else the fire-rate goes down. All this nonsense does is handicap the player.

BUT THAT'S NOT ALL!
Your ship has a shield of sorts. It recharges very quickly
commentsCount: but you won't survive more than two hits or a collision. From what little of this game I could stand
column16: it isn't exactly clear how much damage a bullet does. Your shield has five blips
column17: but a bullet can take 2 or 3 or 4? It doesn't make any sense. When your shield is drained
column18: a high-pitched warning siren that is much louder than anything else in the game assaults you. I'm being completely serious here
column19:
don't play this game while wearing head-phones.

BUT THAT'S CERTAINLY NOT ALL!
The difficulty balance in this game is a complete mess. The beginning of stage 1 is snore-inducing
column20: but then a mecha-scorpion shows up and throws more bullets on-screen than you'll see for the entirety of stage 2. Off-screen enemies will also continually fire at you
column21: and there's nothing you can do about that. Even though the game gives you 9 lives and a shield of questionable effectiveness
column22: you're probably going to lose it all to the mecha-scorpion. This guy is a mountain of bull-♥♥♥♥. First off his attack pattern consists of a steady stream of lasers. He never lets up
column23: and the waves of fire are more intense than anything prior to this fight. You're going to be completely unprepared for this fight
column24:
simply because you never got the mental training.

OH NO! THAT'S ABSOLUTELY NOT ♥♥♥♥ING ALL!

During this fight
column26: and there are objects to run into such as walls. Hanging as far away from the boss as possible
column27: isn't really a viable tactic. Furthermore
column28: after you destroy the scorpion's claws and tail armor
column29: he doubles up on the lasers. What was originally a really tight fit is now practically impossible. Luckily there's a safe spot if you hang out just under his tail...BUT...without any warning at all the scorpion will rush forward and smash you. There is absolutely no possible way for you to know the scorpion would do that
column30: unless you designed the game. I'm going to guess that C-RUSH didn't have any testers
column31: because anyone would know that such a sudden attack without any warning is awful game-design. The worst part is that just before the fight
column32: a couple of hornets attack the player-ship by flying into it. They actually point out where they're going to go
column33: so the player knows to get out of the way. Before I give too much credit
column34: C-RUSH also doesn't warn the player about enemies approaching from behind.\n\nDon't bother with this game
column36: but when I'm given the choice between writing a mean-spirited review or putting a keyboard through my monitor
column37: I'll choose the review every time."

reviewText:
This is a great little game. I admit I was disappointed at first  to see no mouse compatibility in-game, it's played entirely with keyboard. Just a preference of mine I always hope to see, but I shouldn't be surprised there isn't one here.
I only encountered one small bug with the in-game pause menu but this may only be an issue for me.

There is a huge lack of options under the settings with just fullscreen on/off, difficulty, key bindings and one other which I don't know what it is. This doesn't bother me at all, but is something others might want to take into account.
There is no customization for your ship whatsoever that I can see. Powerups are temporary and primarily obtained by destroying enemies, otherwise there is no weapon or ship upgrades. You can flip your ship around for slower, more accurate attacks and dodging. The dodging seems forced in some areas however to get you to actually use your ship on it's side, because it's very easy to just leave your ship flat and spam the two, faster guns.
Also I didn't seem to notice a scoreboard, though I did notice something about my score being uploaded. I'm not sure if there's a place online to view leaderboards; it would be nice as that is the game's point.

I'm giving this a thumbs up, why? Because for it's price this game is an amazing grab. The controls are responsive, the game is pleasing to look at; the hit-boxes are forgiving, maybe too forgiving for your enemies, but that can just add to the challenge. So there's only one level? So this is only $2.00 and I think a lot of work went into this for that price despite what it lacks. I'm enjoying this game for what it is, who isn't going to give a game a thumbs up if they're enjoying it?

reviewText:
Length of Time Played: 20 Minutes
Distance Played: Made it to Stage 2 before quitting

Opinion of Each Aspect (Sorted By Importance)

Grading System - Outstanding, Excellent, Good, Acceptable, Poor, Horrendous, Abysmal

Gameplay: Horrendous
Controls: Abysmal
Stability: Poor
Difficulty: Poor
Sounds: Acceptable
Graphics: Good
Music: Good
Story: N/A

Other Notes:
Ease of 100% Achievements: Insanely Difficult - You try not dying once and see how hard it is.
Replay Value: None - Go find a better Shmup, there are tons of them.
No Originality - This game provides nothing new to the Shmup genre. Many other games do it better.
Control Scheme - What kind of backwards default keybindings are these?!
Limited Firepower - You have to keep killing enemies and getting orbs. Powerups are mostly useless.

Personal Grade: F

reviewText: C-RUSH is a sci-fi 2D shooter with a couple cool ideas, game gives the option to double your firing space so you can hit two enemy units at the same time, and a normal one fire shot which is more powerful. There is a blaster fuel bar, which you will have to maintain to keep it on the highest damage level by constantly recharging it with passing the special stations on the go. The controls are your old buddy WSAD or arrows and any button to shoot, but you will have to setup it first, since it’s not comfortable for the user by default. You are tasked to do a normal type of fly and shoot missions with constant obstacles on the way and the epic boss at the end of it all. Might feel a bit hard at the beginning but practice do the wonders. The graphic is surprisingly high. A game will be a new addition for gamers who r into 2d shooters to test their skills, though any gamer might find in it something special for himself to enjoy.

reviewText:
The game looks and sounds great, but unfortunatley the controls are not that good and that makes the game unplayable.

The controls are too touchy. Navigating through the small passages without hitting the walls or trying to move around enemies without accidently touching them is very difficult. You will lose most of your lives in this game not from getting hit by enemy fire, but from accidently touching a wall or an enemy ship.

I used a controller setup with rapid fire, so anything in front of me was going to be destroyed (as long as I could line up the shot with the touchy controls). Even with that, after playing for an hour, I could not get through the first level.

I enjoy difficult games that have a learning curve, but this game is difficult for the wrong reasons.

reviewText: Very short and somewhat fun shmup but a lot of people, including me, have trouble running the game. Half of the time I tried to play this, it kept crashing and doing funny things to my system (like running about 20 instances of FFDShow at the same time for some reason). Also, the last level (or should I say sub-level, as the game is generally one level divided into four sections) seems buggy and it loops until I lose all my ships. It happens every time and honestly, I don't feel like trying again to see if this time the game doesn't get buggy. I got this as a part of a bundle and I regret adding this to my collection. Maybe I wouldn't  if the devs atually cared about this game. A lot of people complain about bugs but the devs don't give a damn. Do yourself a favour and avoid this little piece of turd.

reviewText:
YAS (Yet Another SHUMP)

Pro:
Looks OK
It it what it is
OK controls
Cheap / bundled

Con:
No steam cards
Only 1 ship
2 difficulty modes
No F12 capture

Overall:
5/10 (-1lack of options) = 4/10
So we're back to needing a thumbs sideways.


If you like SHUMPS but don't need a very good version then get this game.  If you like SHUMPS and get it free in a bundle play it.  If you don't care for SHUMPS, this will not make you like them.

It's not bad for a shump, so thumbs up. (Just)

reviewText: I love 2d shooters and I love gradius type games, but wow, simply stunned at how fast I put this game down and whacked my head against the keyboard. Plays great on a control, but with so much grand 2d shooters in the market, this one definetly feels like it was rushed. Hence the name i guess? The first screen looks awesome, and then it stops, moving beehive cells are your background, throughout everywhere, I'm not sure if they really tried to be unique or simply got lazy half ways but same ol enemies bland backgrounds, with really bad powerups make this game very forgetable. Try it if its on sale, it is hard, somewhat. You do get shields and have lives to waste, but if you played bullet hell games, it actually isn't that hard, it just feels so empty when you play it. Maybe if you were high on something might you find this game entertaining, the background sort of pulses and you can shoot some of the level away. Bosses are alright but at just a coupld of them and no checkpoint save system, it feels like a chore to come back to it and pass it, I would rather fish in World of Warcraft than play this anytime soon.

reviewText:
I'm not sure why this game gets as many negative reviews as it does.  It's not a great game, for sure, but it's not bad either.  It's nice and solid 'okay.'

The first time I played this was on a keyboard - other than the menus the game has no mouse support - and admittedly, even with rebinding the keys, I found the controls to be a bit on the clunky side and not as responsive as I would have liked.  I recently added an x-box controller and came back to this game and using the controller instead of keyboard is a world of difference.

A tutorial, or at least a tutorial-esque splash screen, would have been nice.  There are these tanks that shoot out different colored gas and it took a few games until I realized that you're not supposed to avoid the gas but actually go into it to recharge your weapons.

But as I said, the game is okay.  There is nothing stellar about it but so far nothing horrible either.  I guess the biggest crutch I've seen is I don't see that sense of addictive fun where you're mindlessly popping quarters into the figurative arcade machine to see if you can make it just a little bit further this time.  It's something you play for a little bit and then forget about, and then down the road when you're looking for a shoot-em-up, you can play this one again for a little bit too.

reviewText:
Background: Picked up for next to nothing in a bundle

The Good:
* Nice bold design work (probably due to mobile device target platform)
* Initially seems interesting

The Bad:
* Keyboard layout makes no sense.
* Controller overrides keyboard
* Shooting mechanic changes without warning
* No resolution control
* Predictable attack waves

Impressions: If this is a work in progress it's worth a minimal price (pennies/cents) for a side scroller with some original looking enemies attacking in generic waves.

Recommended for: Low stakes, side scrolling shooter to pass some time.

Conclusion: 3/10. Okay as a work in progress (will upgrade review if so) but worthless if this is it.
